review:
Eyes of Wakanda is one of those rare Marvel ventures that stops you in your tracks not because of big explosions or flashy cameos, but because it's unapologetically beautiful and deeply thoughtful. From the opening sequence, it felt less like a cartoon and more like a living, breathing piece of art. The show leans into a hand painted animation style inspired by Ernie Barnes and Dean Cornwell, creating visuals that critics describe as "a moving painting" that truly honors Wakanda's soul.

Across its four episodes, each story shines: Episode One's mission to Crete is high stakes and emotionally resonant; Episode Three's ancient Iron Fist arc connects legacy and mythology in a way that feels earned, not forced. I found myself fully immersed in the moral dilemmas-loyalty vs duty, isolation vs expansion-that feel like Black Panther elevated to its most cerebral form.

Some critics pointed out pacing issues and storytelling shortcuts due to the short format and they're right. A few arcs, especially in the middle, feel undercooked and don't get the emotional payoff they deserve. But the finale ties it all together beautifully, exploring legacy and sacrifice and literally weaving in Black Panther lore in a smart, satisfying callback - a payoff that made my heart skip a beat.

It's frustrating knowing this four episode miniseries is getting unjust one star reviews from people who only hate downvote because of the lead characters, not because they watched. That noise doesn't reflect what this story is doing. Eyes of Wakanda shows that Marvel still knows how to deliver emotionally rich, intelligent storytelling through animation.

This isn't just filler content-it's a bold experiment that pays off and shows what Marvel can do when it leans into art, history, and cultural weight instead of chasing trends. I came away feeling both inspired and hungry for more.

Rating: 9/10 ambitious, beautiful, insightful. Eyes of Wakanda sets a new standard for what animated Marvel stories can and should be.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: universalarghyaroy
review:
As a long-time fan of the Marvel Universe, I went into Eyes of Wakanda hoping to experience something fresh, powerful, and unique-especially considering the rich legacy of Wakanda and Black Panther. Unfortunately, what I got was a dull, uninspired anthology that completely misses the mark.

The show consists of four episodes, each telling a different story, but the frustrating part is-they all follow the same exact plot structure. Different characters, different settings, yet somehow every episode feels like a recycled version of the last. There's no narrative progression, no emotional payoff, and no sense of originality. It's like watching the same uninspired script played out four times in a row, and by the third episode, I was already fighting off sleep.

What makes this even more disappointing is the expectation. When you hear "Wakanda" or "Black Panther," you naturally anticipate something extraordinary-something filled with culture, depth, and innovation. Eyes of Wakanda delivers none of that. There's no improvisation, no risks, and no standout characters or moments. Even the animation, while decent, can't save the lackluster storytelling.

It feels like Ryan Coogler may have had a vision for this project, and the effort from the creative team is evident-but somewhere along the way, that vision got lost. Instead of celebrating Wakanda's mystique and legacy, the series reduces it to a repetitive fetch-quest formula that goes nowhere.

In a franchise known for boldness and world-building, this series is shockingly forgettable. I genuinely wanted to like it, but Eyes of Wakanda left me bored, frustrated, and ultimately disappointed. I don't usually say this about Marvel content, but this felt like a complete waste of time.

Marvel can and should do better than this.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: Nomad007
review_title: Boring - Really Wanted To Like It.
review:
When I heard this was coming out I was excited. Ad to that the people involved in the film are involved in this animation franchise.

But watching it is just so dull, boring, and completely uninteresting.

I tried to watch as much as I could tolerate to give it a fair shake but it's just horriable.

I wish I had anything positive to say about it.

But just stay away.

Besides it's Disney+ so even if you like it the will cancel it after one season like they do with 99% of their shows.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: SHU_Movies
review:
Marvel Studios' Eyes Of Wakanda is a four-part anthology series, with each episode following a different Wakandan War Dog during different time periods. With the nice animation, good action, well thought-through stories and interesting characters, it's a moderately entertaining mini-series that expands nicely on the lore of the Wakanda in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

It may not necessarily be a good series, but it's definitely enjoyable. Unfortunately, there are way better ways to pass a couple of hours, and the contents of this series could quite easily be summarised in a 60-second video on YouTube or TikTok. Because of this, I wouldn't recommend it to casual fans. I'd only suggest that you watch it if you're a hardcore fan of the MCU, or you're a fan of Marvel Comics (because Episode 3 made me very happy as someone that's been a life-long fan of a particular mystical character).

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: simbiat
review:
Like... Why? I seriously do not get the point of these shorts. They did not explore much (if anything) about Wakanda. They seemingly did not expand MCU either. They just forced people from Wakanda into various time periods and locations, where they may or may not make any sense. Especially with the interpretation of Trojan War in 2nd episode. Which is, indeed, the strongest episode of the 4. Probably because half of it is not original.

Visually it's ok. Not bad, not particularly good. At least, not that good to be the reason to even make this thing. It does not explore anything interesting like "What If?", and I do not think there are easter eggs for Marvel fans. Unless you want to count an Iron Fist in 3rd episode, but it could have been any other Chinese woman, really.

And the tech? Oh, it does not make sense. Long distance communication device during Trojan War? Seriously? Vibranium was a awesome, yes, but it did not automatically turn everyone around it into geniuses, who could transcend time and space in their minds. This was clearly written by people who do not understand how technology evolved through-out human history. Even Assassin's Creed makes more sense when they drop some futuristic tech in those games.

Only saving grace here, is that there are just 4 episodes, but is that a good enough justification to watch these? I'm not sure.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: JCeran
review:
Eyes of Wakanda is visually stunning, with beautiful animation that really brings the world of Wakanda to life. The storytelling is creative, and the music adds to the experience. I also appreciated the tie-ins to the larger Marvel universe-those moments were a treat for longtime fans.

That said, while the show had a strong foundation, it felt like it didn't quite go the distance. The story was engaging, but something was missing-perhaps a deeper emotional core or more time to let the characters breathe. The short runtime didn't help; just as things got interesting, the episode(s) seemed to end.

Overall, I liked Eyes of Wakanda, but I wanted more-more depth, more time, and maybe just a little more of that Marvel magic.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: wcparry2
review_title: Looks nice, sounds about as good as nails on a chalkboard, and girlpowering along with bad writing, make it typical post-phase 1 trash
review: Looks nice, sounds about as good as nails on a chalkboard, and girlpowering along with bad writing, make it typical post-phase 1 trash. Absolute a drippy mess of feces. Trying to buy into cultural relevance by rewriting things and good lord, that screeching at the end of every show that is given to us as "music" is nauseating. I want my money back, and this cost me nothing to watch. Except my sanity. Disney will never learn, and it is glorious watching their downfall. A 3rd grader with crayons could have written a better and more deep show. Pathetic.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: LeonardoOliva69
review_title: An interesting but unnecessary series, let's be honest, nobody is going to watch it...
review:
Here again for a new Marvel product that no one asked for but that came out.

It's hard to think about who approves all these projects these days, and no one realizes that what the MCU needed was to get back to its roots so it could be reborn.

Is "Eyes of Wakanda" a bad series? No, it isn't.

Is it an unnecessary series? Absolutely.

It's with this premise that I sat down to watch the series, and it's really not bad. It has interesting points, expands the lore and history of Wakanda over hundreds of years, and even has a time-travel episode that ties in with the first film.

However, let's be honest, no one is going to watch this series, and just as there was no promotion for it, it will pass unnoticed on streaming. Only MCU fans and content creators will dedicate a few lines to it and then move on to more interesting projects.

All this makes me wonder if there's a future for this universe. After all, "Avengers: Doomsday" is just around the corner, and everything that preceded it and the current news suggests a huge disaster.

That must be why "Eyes of Wakanda" will be underrated despite having a couple of interesting concepts and many good things.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: jared-25331
review:
Eyes of Wakanda (2025) is the fourth entry in the Black Panther franchise and it is set in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Now this is a show I went into with low expectations and I liked it a lot.

Positives for Eyes of Wakanda (2025): The animation for this show looks amazing. I like the idea of traveling throughout different timelines in Wakanda and seeing different characters doing things. There are some fun action sequences in these 4 episodes. The characters are interesting and you want to see more of them. And finally, this show is easy to binge through on Disney+.

Negatives for Eyes of Wakanda (2025): There are only 4 episodes in the mini series which is fine enough, but I wanted more from the story. I wanted to see more of Wakanda and what it was like before the character we have come to know. And finally, this mini series only exists because Disney needed something for people to watch on Disney+.

Overall, Eyes of Wakanda (2025) is a good animated mini series that did a good job at exploring the world of Wakanda in the past, but I also wanted more from this series.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: JontaeS-0
review: Absolutely loved it!! It was masterfully crafted from the colors, special effects and fighting sequence. I appreciated how they were able to show different cultural beliefs and history while intersecting Wakanda history in as well. The story lines were great and did not leave you with the feeling of how did that happen or where did that come from. All episodes tied into each other even though they were spaced out throughout history's timeline and wrap it up perfectly so that it ends where Black Panther begins.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: thomasubieda
review:
A miniseries that expands the lore of Wakanda, adding interesting details and leaving room for certain debates. It has attractive concept art.

"Eyes of Wakanda" is an entertaining, simple, and very acceptable proposal due to the addition of narrative aspects that in a way promote the entire environment of Wakanda, its beginnings, or stages at various points in time. It can be very entertaining depending on your expectations or very mediocre in what it aims to convey, however, it has merit in terms of all its elaboration and the work behind the final result.

It's one of those Marvel productions that tries a twist on animation, and it's fine; all that visual aspect is reflected on screen and it has pleasant moments. I can highlight the overall concept art, which has a level of detail, creativity, and ingenuity that dazzles at all times. The ability to encompass that original style and the designs in the stories deserves a great point. Each of the environments seen in the episodes is striking and full of energy.

There are 4 episodes that cover different stories, themes, objectives, and reflections that come together to somewhat complement the ideals of a resource-rich country in different eras, all with the aim of creating a coherent link with characters already seen in the 2018 movie "Black Panther." Being able to see certain small details, references, stories, and the introduction of new characters, I believe, fulfills in some way.

It should be noted that it is not an animated miniseries that will revolutionize the Marvel universe, but it can entertain true fans. In addition, from my perspective, it is not the best of all Marvel Animation productions either; works like "X-Men 97" or "Your Friendly Neighborhood Spider-Man" are better, emphasizing plot, impactful moments, animation, and story. Even so, "Eyes of Wakanda" can be enjoyed.

The animation seems well-crafted to me, it has nuances, colors, designs, sequences, and attractive designs, its goal is well-deserved. Despite that, there's a small detail about the characters' gaze or facial features that doesn't quite convince me. The environments, locations, and so on are very well done. The musical score carries weight within the plot.

Now then, each episode has questionable details, whether due to conventions, the strength of the script, better execution of the development, more engaging plots, or exploiting the potential they had. It is evident that there are one or two episodes that leave much to be desired, whether due to the narrative argument or character development. In my experience, the second episode is the best due to the connection established in various parts through the protagonists' goals, covering real historical themes and certain creative details.

"Eyes of Wakanda" serves as another window to provide stories that can be entertaining for many viewers, fulfilling in certain details, but dividing the critics considerably. Ryan Coogler's work and his love for the culture are evident.

The essence of the comics is present and appreciated. It's a product that could have been much better, but it works. The added characters have their importance, and especially those connections with the live-action movies. Iron Fist is back in the house.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: Chrystiand
review:
I hadn't even heard about The Eyes of Wakanda until it popped up on my Disney+ dashboard. To be honest, it didn't immediately grab my attention. Given the uneven quality of recent Disney/Marvel projects, I went in with low expectations-and I couldn't have been more wrong.

The animation is absolutely stunning, hooking me from the very first frame. I'm genuinely impressed by how the creators managed to craft a compelling story across just four episodes, especially when it initially seemed like it might lack structure. While I wouldn't call it the best thing I've ever seen, it's undeniably entertaining-enough to binge all four episodes in one afternoon.

I highly recommend giving The Eyes of Wakanda a watch. It's engaging, cleverly weaves in elements of Wakandan lore, and introduces some intriguing aspects of its history in a fresh and inventive way.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: Martin_Pyramid
review:
I was far from being impressed with this one. The stories felt unimportant and sometimes not particularly enjoyable, mostly due to unpleasant main characters. The heroes are so focused on coming back with the stolen artifact from Wakanda, but it's hard to care about this kind of mission, and sometimes the "enemies" feel more right and easy to relate.

I don't think they were successful in their way to include Wakanda heroes into real historical events, or at least popular myth, like the Trojan horse. It feels out of place and they don't take advantage of them to make impactful arguments about our history.

The art was not that great either, not a big fan of how they made the faces, they all look like they have too much makeup on. There are some beautiful moments there, but the overreliance on "yellow rays of light" makes everything too dull when it could have had a brighter contrast.

The action scenes were as good as you can expect from Marvel, with very well-choreographed fights.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: calahao
review:
Eyes of Wakanda is an anthology series that worldbuilds on the nation and it's people across history. Each episode focuses on a different Wakandan agent either retrieving something stolen from Wakanda or a threat to the kingdom.

The animation is a painted CGI style, similar to the previous "What If..." in some ways. The characters have pleasant designs, with quite some diversity in female facial features, as if defying classical Disney "wisdom".

A strong recommendation.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: Itzbm06
review: I was expecting the show to be pretty bad but it's Okay. The animation was pretty solid episode one and three were the worst ones. In my opinion they were boring. The story was kind of iffy and episode three was probably the worst because they made iron fist, a female, which I am not happy about but episodes two and four were actually the better ones and the last episode kind of sets up towards the first Black Panther movie, which was pretty interesting on how they did that. I don't think I could recommend this show.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: BretM-3
review: I had relatively low expectations for this series. Four, thirty minute episodes, and the fact that the last time Ryan Coogler was advertised as being a TV show producer for Marvel (Ironheart) I was a little underwhelmed. But this show really surprised me and ended up earning a well deserved spot amongst the 10/10 knockouts that have been Black Panther centric stories, and the almost 10/10 line of Marvel Animation shows (save for What If..? Season 3). The animation is beautiful and is up to Marvel Animation standards. It's very similar to the animation of "What If..?", rather than "X-Men '97" or "Your Friendly Neighborhood Spider-Man." But in particular I thought the underwater sequences in episode one were stunning! The action sequences were also great and I really enjoyed the fight choreography across the board for all episodes. I also thought the cast of characters were interesting and played well by their actors. My biggest complaint is that it feels like it needs to be longer! 1 thirty minute episode doesn't do enough to make these characters memorable or desirable to see again, mainly due to low character development. The biggest exception to this is Iron Fist! I want more Iron Fist in the MCU! I also think 4 episodes is a bit too short for my taste, I prefer 6 episode runs like "Loki." So my biggest advice for Marvel is: Do a Season 2, make the episodes longer, and give me more of them!

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: imdbfan-455259
review: Eyes of Wakanda is such a beautiful and amazingly told story. I am thoroughly satisfied, entertain and pleased with everything that was done with this project. I appreciate every creative that worked on it. The script was more amazing than you would expect a animated miniseries to be, and I truly appreciate the fact that they were able to tie in spoilers for the future of the direction of Wakanda as well as linked the past and bring it to one beautiful ark that is the eyes of Wakanda. Bravo.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: EODGhost
review:
4 episodes, all the same basic plot line. Although visually attractive, the characters were not. I don't understand why all the female characters appeared to have microcephaly. Big faces, small craniums; it was bizarre and creepy. They all spoke with these commanding, girl-boss voices, but didn't have much substance in their dialogue. Like, "I'm tough, not really smart, but I think I sound tough." I think therefore I am. Nope. You look mentally deficient, and tough talk doesn't make up for that. More girl-boss BS and the writers are tone deaf to viewers. Pretty much tired of that since CPT Marvel, and you keep trying to cram that nonsense down our throats.

This series is simply lipstick on a pig. Spoiler alert, It's still a pig. Hard pass.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: jaysmoke
review:
It's okay! If you've seen Predator: Killer of Killers, Spiderverse, or Arcane, this one might not impress you as much. It was decent for the most part, but the stories weren't particularly amazing-they were just average.

That said, I did enjoy the fight scenes and the tech; those were definite highlights.

One thing I honestly couldn't stand was the accent-it was horrendous. Why couldn't they just speak in a native tongue like the Japanese or Italians do in this same series? Instead, they went with this awkward, forced English accent that just didn't work.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: stefantodorovic-13218
review_title: This is a very good show!
review:
Eyes of Wakanda is, without exaggeration, one of the most stunning projects Marvel has ever put out. From the first frame, it's clear this series is something special. The animation style is breathtaking - every shot feels like a hand-crafted painting brought to life, rich with detail and bursting with color, yet never losing that grounded, lived-in feeling of Wakanda's world.

The storytelling is tight, sharp, and emotional. Each episode dives into a different era and mission, following Wakanda's elite operatives as they risk everything to protect their nation and recover Vibranium artifacts across the globe. What's remarkable is how much depth they manage to pack into short episodes. The pacing never drags, and the tone balances action, history, and emotional weight perfectly.

What truly makes Eyes of Wakanda worthy of a 10/10 is how it expands the MCU without feeling like filler. Every mission matters, every character feels alive, and the stakes are both personal and global. You get to see sides of Wakanda we've never explored in the films - the shadows behind the throne, the untold sacrifices, and the moral dilemmas that come with guarding a secret as powerful as Vibranium.

The action choreography is fluid and inventive, using the animation medium to deliver sequences that would be impossible in live-action. But it's not just spectacle - the series has real heart. There are moments that hit you emotionally, from personal sacrifices to connections with the events of Black Panther. It's layered, thoughtful, and still manages to be a thrill ride.

Simply put, Eyes of Wakanda doesn't just meet expectations, it surpasses them. It's Marvel at its boldest - visually stunning, narratively rich, and emotionally resonant. For fans and newcomers alike, it's an easy, unquestionable 10/10. Wakanda Forever.

title: Eyes of Wakanda
author: JustinV-197
review_title: One of Marvel's Best - Eyes of Wakanda Review
review:
Man, I didn't expect much from Eyes of Wakanda, but it totally blew my mind.

Hands down, one of the best Marvel series I've ever watched. I honestly thought it was gonna be some slow, boring side-story, but I was completely wrong. The storytelling, animation, and world-building were all top-tier. It expands the Wakandan lore in such a badass and meaningful way. Marvel really nailed this one. üëèüòå

It's a must-watch - more of this, Marvel.

Keep it coming!

Wakanda Forever.

title: Marvel Zombies

title: Marvel Zombies

review: Everything is amazing hear I don't know how to explain, i screamed so much when i watch the every second and the Wanda (mother) is everything hear she's the hope,Marvel have no idea what she did what she have, she has potential we need Elizabeth in live action immediately,this series have multiple Epic moment, i need season 2.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: petemclaughlin-24277
review:
Ive just come across this new animated adventure that has had zero advertising or promotion from what ive seen. Usually you get something, especially as it seems its in the same animation style as the 'What if?' saga. After around 5 minutes of viewing you can see why. Now i am a massive fan of the What if? Series, all 3 seasons. I know critically the last season wasnt recieved well but i enjoyed it all the same

Marvel Zombies starts with new batch of annoying young characters that have had marvel fans tuning out for years and its clear to see within the opening few scenes. Theyve (again) positioned Riri as this amazing genius amd the leader of this little pack and the writing is just atrocious. What we had with the old Avengers dynamics is that each character would shine in their own way but not at the expense of the others. What you always have here is a constant bombardment of how much of a genius Riri is without any reason as to why. What you do get in this little group dynamic is that each character is written dumber so that Riri can spell out the obvious thus elevating her to the smartest in the room. Unfortunately, if the audience doesnt have an IQ of 10 then its painfully obvious that its framed this way. Tony Stark was written with conflict within which ever group he was in, it made sense for this arrogance as his brilliance always over shined that and it also wasnt at the expense of the other characters. Here its just a race to the bottom and unfortunately, because of this, it does not have the same charm as the what if series and clearly ranks in a time when the writing was so bad that it destroyed and franchise.

No wonder this wasnt promoted, you can see why disney wanted this to disappear into the night just like Ironheart

the quicker we get past this phase amd get back to interesting stories with flawed characters, the better.

Absolutely awful.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: Kristf-0
review:
There was a lot of potential in this series, but all the characters in it are not enough even by the MCU scale (except Blade, he was just good). I think it was a big mistake to make Ms. Marvel and other not-so-popular characters as main characters, and those who would have been interesting were given little time. Now it would have been possible to bring in an X-Men or other unseen character, even if it's not canon. I really don't understand why there wasn't anyone popular in it, because I understand that they didn't want to synchronize them and save money, but they still included, say, Black Panther, Captain America, who didn't have a single line, so why couldn't they have brought back Iron Man, or Black Widow, or anyone, at least as a zombies?

This series was made in the current MCU concept, regardless it's full of gore,but they try to say something funny in every 3 episodes,like this series made for younger people. The best example of this is Red Guardian, who I thought would be made a little more mature after The Thunderbolts. The biggest stupidity is related to him and his family, specifically at the end of every episode one of them dies by sacrificing themselves,after Yelena sacrificed herself, all I could do was hold my head, because her mother had done exactly that an episode before, so both of them had done it completely unnecessarily.

The only good what liked in this series was Blade,and the final battle,but it was also short, and I missed the more familiar characters there too.

In conclusion, I don't understand why they couldn't use the original comics as a basis. I had the same problem with What If, instead of doing something original, even if it's not canon, they stick to the characters known from the MCU movies.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: clubbythaseal
review_title: Overfilled with Marvel/Disney "They fly now" type humor
review:
I'm struggling to even finish this show because every scene of horror is juxtaposed with this humor that just feels so out of place here.

Why in God's name does there have to be this type of humor in a series that should be just horror. It has more quick jokes in it than Winter soldier did.

I shouldn't have gotten my hopes up after how bad the TV episode was from a few years ago.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: stefantodorovic-13218
review:
Marvel Zombies - A 10/10 Experience

Marvel Zombies is one of those rare stories that takes a familiar universe and turns it completely upside down in the most creative, horrifying, and entertaining way possible. From the very first page, it hooks you with a chilling premise: what if Earth's mightiest heroes were infected with a virus that turns them into flesh-eating monsters? What follows is a brilliant blend of horror, dark comedy, and twisted superhero action that feels fresh and unforgettable.

The writing is sharp, unapologetically brutal, and at times surprisingly witty. Characters you've known for years are shown in a completely new light, not just as heroes, but as corrupted figures driven by hunger and instinct. Seeing icons like Spider-Man, Iron Man, and Captain America struggling against (or fully embracing) their monstrous urges is both unsettling and fascinating. It's a story that doesn't shy away from pushing boundaries, and that's exactly what makes it so compelling.

The art complements the tone perfectly-gruesome when it needs to be, but also detailed enough to show the tragic expressions behind the zombies' faces. It strikes a balance between grotesque and stylish, keeping you engaged without ever feeling repetitive.

What makes Marvel Zombies a perfect 10/10 for me is its ability to shock while still being deeply entertaining. It's not just gore for the sake of gore; there's genuine imagination behind every twist, every downfall, and every haunting "what if" scenario. It expands the Marvel mythos in a way that feels bold and experimental, and it leaves you thinking about it long after you've put it down.

Marvel Zombies isn't just a comic-it's an experience, and one that I'd recommend to any fan of superheroes, horror, or just bold storytelling.

Final Verdict: 10/10.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: captainx-60308
review:
As usual wanda takes space more than she really deserves i feel really sad for how they have been treating thor since infinity war my goat has been destroyed by everyone at least don't put him in the story bro why are u keep doing this thor still has a lot of fans such as me.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: RomanK-628

This series is just terrible. Spit in the face of comic book fans. I have nothing more to say.

Why make a fairy tale out of this universe? This comic book series is horror for adults. It was probably the last chance for Marvel. But this is not only a terrible adaptation (they came up with a mess), but also a damn hack job. Cheap 3d animation... I'd rather read the comics again... And I'll cry...

title: Marvel Zombies
author: augusthorn-27918
review: The story has interesting ideas and ambitions, but unfortunately, Kamala-who serves as the protagonist-is written in a way that feels overly naive and out of place. In a dark and complex narrative, a character so idealized, always positive and striving to be the moral center, clashes with the tone. Thankfully, the show isn't completely ruined, but they will need to either reconsider the choice of protagonist or significantly rethink her portrayal to make the story truly compelling.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: CandyReaper
review:
SPOILER ALERT The starting was good but became meh somewhere along. Wasn't much of an Ironheart fan and now I've come to not like Ms Marvel either. I mean who the hell would ever believe a literal zombie, especially the scarlet witch whose main power is mind manipulation and also killed your friends and everyone who helped you along the way during time of crisis. And what's the disrespect to Thor, I mean, okay he's depressed and all that still... he's all sparks when fighting Wanda but the moment he becomes a rotting zombie he starts bringing down lightning 10 times the size he said was the biggest lightning he ever made in Ragnarok like nothing. Also the Moon Knight Blade who can be considered almost immortal dies in vain to Thor. And PLOTHOLE the Stormbreaker that Thanos destroys with the power stone magically reappears in the end. Another PLOTHOLE Thor lying unconcious near the explosion of Infinity Stones said to be extremely lethal survives. Adding another point, okay Nova Corps might quarantine the zombie infested planet to prevent its spread but who in their right mind would leave it to fester like that for years? Especially if its a planet where the Mad Titan was last seen and people like Tony Stark who is said to be known across the galaxy for his intellect. They would try to cure or eradicate it by sending some robots or other similar beings that won't be affected by zombies. Also again at Kamala who would ever believe and the take the hand of the zombie that killed their friends. The ONLY thing a psycho zombie can mean when it says it can fix everything would be making everyone zombies.

PS: Disney please stop creating a series when you see the audience like a genre and stretch it until you can squeeze every buck from it. It will destroy series with nice potentials.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: abalpn-99472
review:
What could be better than to see more zombies in the multiple universes? This series has it! The action, drama and the gory stuff. Disney and Marvel have done it again. I've watched the episodes from "What If...?" and we get to see more zombies.

It's like The Walking Dead and The Last of Us mixed into this style. The atmosphere of the entire animation is dark and that's what I like about it.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: rjmandhane
review:
Marvel *did not* hold back!

This series goes full TV-MA, with zombified heroes getting absolutely wrecked - blood, guts, and savage takedowns left and right. It's basically Marvel finally letting the gloves come off, and it's a gorefest fans have been screaming for!

Got serious comic vibes, too. Unexpected crossovers everywhere (like Blade rocking Moon Knight moves, Kamala leading the squad, and Spider-Man going full web-head decapitation mode), plus wild team-ups and power mashups you'll never see in regular MCU. Feels like the writers just grabbed random hero cards and said "Let's smash!" - pure fan service, but in the best way.

And that ending? Bro, they hit us with a reality-glitch cliffhanger that's total Phase 6 chaos. Kamala and Wanda's mind games are next level, and season 2 is practically begging for a comeback.

If you ever wanted actual Marvel carnage, this is it. R-rated, loaded with Easter eggs, bananas character moments (rip to a ton of OG heroes), and somehow still a blast. Excelsior, Marvel maniacs - this ain't kiddie pool stuff, it's the real zombie apocalypse we deserve.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: FiftyTwo_52
review_title: Dead on Arrival: Skip This Shambling Snoozefest
review:
Oh, Disney+, what fresh hell is this?

Marvel Zombies' Ep 1 lurches onto screens like a reanimated roadkill, promising undead thrills but delivering a snooze-fest that makes paint drying look like a blockbuster.

Twenty minutes in, and I tapped out... because life's too short for this zombie apocalypse of boredom.

Where's the story? Buried under a pile of aimless scavenging and contrived "team-building" chit-chat that drags like a legless ghoul. Kamala, Riri, and Kate bicker through filler dialogues so wooden, you'd swear they were scripted by a committee of comatose interns. "Hope's just bait"? More like the only bait here is the audience, hooked and reeled into tedium.

And the animation? Average at best... stiff, soulless cel-shading that wouldn't pass muster in a Saturday morning rerun. Gory kills? Laughable; they feel as impactful as swatting flies.

After "Creature Commandos" raised the bar with razor-sharp wit, grotesque genius, and actual momentum, this is a gut-punch reminder: not every B-team swing connects.

Skip it. Stream something with a pulse.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: n00bmast3r69
review_title: I wanted to like it but...

Cons: Ironheart and Ms. Marvel, not a big fan of their characters. They are both very annoying. So overall, I don't think it's a terrible show, but it ain't that good either aside from Wanda as an antagonist and the gory violence.

title: Marvel Zombies

If in the last episode you think of a banal ending, rest assured that it is that.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: Tamerbulgari
review:
From the very first episode, Marvel Zombies proved to be a miniature cinematic masterpiece that exceeded expectations and more. In just four episodes, the series succeeded in presenting a fully integrated world pulsating with excitement and suspense, with fast-paced events that kept the viewer engaged until the very last moment.

The story was brilliant, with an exciting pace that kept you eager for what would happen next. The clever use of characters was a highlight; not only were they featured, but they were also cleverly employed, giving each character a distinct dimension. Wanda appeared as we know her: an unstoppable force, while the Hulk, with his immense powers powered by the Infinity Stones, astonished in a fantastic and dazzling battles. Kamala Khan, on the other hand, brought a refreshing spirit that made her the beating heart of the series, and the presence of Blade Moon Knight was undeniable, with all his magnificence and charisma.

The graphics and animation were top-notch, giving the series a luxurious visual dimension befitting the Marvel Universe. The violence and gore were presented with boldness and professionalism, making it arguably one of Marvel's best in this regard. Added to this is the legendary music that deepened the atmosphere and gave every moment its dramatic weight.

Although the series is almost devoid of moments of boredom, the open and shocking ending may leave the viewer thirsty for more. Nevertheless, the work remains well-rounded, blending visual power and dramatic depth into an unforgettable experience.

Ultimately, Marvel Zombies is one of Marvel's most daring and enjoyable works ever. My personal rating: 10/10 ‚≠ê, and recommending it is not optional, but rather a necessity, because it is an experience that any fan of the superhero universe will enjoy.

title: Marvel Zombies
author: LukeD-14
review:
Ok this does have spoilers so do not read!!!!!

The fights the character dynamics EVERYTHING is really good!! But, this was rated as a 16+ on Disney+ so I went in expecting lots of jumpscares and stuff that would genuinely make me shake in fear. But this show didn't do that. Yes there was blood, yes there was gore, but the one thing that was missing was the use of proper horror. But all and all I loved this show and I need season 2 right nowwwwwww! The only thing that's needed is more horror. But MARVEL this was AMAZINGGGGGGGGG!!!!!

title: Wonder Man
author: larosaj-26666
review_title: Makes Madame Web seem like The Avengers
review: The previews looked uninteresting but since it was Marvel I gave it a shot anyway. To my everlasting regret. First problem is I've never particularly liked Yahya. Not in Aquaman, Matrix or Watchmen. He's just not compelling. Then we have Ben reprising his character from Iron Man 3 which let's face it was the worst part of that movie. It doesn't help I never cared for Wonder Man in the comics. I've liked most of the Marvel shows to some degree or other but this is just bad, uninteresting and uninvolving. If you want anything resembling a superhero show you sure won't find it here. I'm all for different stuff like Echo or Moonknight but this was a big zero. This is just a junk drama. Unlike Wandavision which started off bizarre but ended spectacularly this show looks like it's going nowhere. Course I won't be finding out. After the horrendous 4th episode and the usually unlikable Josh Gad being Josh Gad I bowed out. I can't even begin to fathom how some people are enjoying this nothing happening show.

title: Wonder Man
author: dextermorgan-91603
review_title: I'm still WONDERing ... MAN.. how could it be ....
review:
Such hot Garbage? One blunder after another.

Marvel's Wonder Man is a spectacular act of disrespect to Simon Williams and a masterclass in how to waste a character.

In the comics, Simon Williams is a tragic, angry, complicated man-betrayed by his own choices, experimented on by AIM and Baron Zemo, turned into a living ionic weapon, and dragged through guilt, redemption, death, and rebirth. That history matters. It's the entire point of Wonder Man. The fandom page alone has a richer arc than this whole show manages in eight episodes.

The Disney+ series throws all of that straight into the trash and replaces it with a smug, meta, fourth-wall-adjacent Hollywood sitcom that thinks it's clever for mocking itself instead of actually telling a story. AIM? Gone. Zemo? Gone. The experimentation, the moral conflict, the sense that Simon's powers came at a terrible cost?

And no-this isn't about race. Yahya Abdul-Mateen II is a strong actor. But the show gives him nothing to work with. This version of Simon Williams isn't reinvented; he's hollowed out. If you're going to race-swap a character, you'd better honor the core of who he is. This show doesn't. It strips Simon of his comic identity, then wears his name like a costume.

The acting suffers because the writing is terrified of sincerity. Everything is irony. Everything is self-aware. Nothing has weight. No stakes, no mythology, no audience clearly in mind. It's too shallow for comic fans, too inside-baseball for casual viewers, and too cowardly to be real superhero drama.

This isn't an adaptation.

It's an apology for not trying.

title: Wonder Man
author: gandrews978
review_title: As dull as Simon's audition lines
review:
Made it through EP2 and while I'm happy to see Kingsley back as Trevor, I can absolutely not get into this one. The story line is shallow as are the characters. The writers attempt to develop the characters, but have only created a mashup of stereotypes. Marvel has definitely lost it. And to think that someone had to approve, green light and fund this project. There are multiple Easter eggs that give a hat tip to various other Marvel titles.

Sorry Marvel, you lost me after EP2 and it's not worth investing another 3 hrs to watch the rest.

title: Wonder Man

A refreshing Marvel tv-show.

Its not for everyone and its not full of action like your typical Marvel show.

But it does have some great cinematography, with great acting and an interesting story.

I came for Sir Ben Kingsley but stayed for an all-round solid tv show.

The average TikTok kid will probably find it very boring, but maybe its not for you then...

Its also a Quick Watch. 8 - 30 min episodes, 4 hours. Worth a Watch.

7/10.

title: Wonder Man
author: kcrateau
review_title: What am I watching from the MCU
review: I can't for the life of me figure out why people are adoring this show. Three episodes into a Marvel TV show and we have one instance of showing some superpower, but it's been glossed over the whole time. The stupid tension between the brother and his family is just annoying, and this just feels like a family drama series rather than a Marvel superhero series. I've been bored to death and will probably never watch beyond the third episode that I thought was absolutely mind numbingly, slow and dumb.

title: Wonder Man
author: Tamerbulgari
review:
Honestly, I wasn't hyped for this series because the trailer didn't show anything special, but now I'm amazed - I didn't expect it to be this good at all. Sure, it lacks some classic MCU action scenes, but it explores a whole new genre, something no one did before.

What really worked for me was the tone, the friendship, the characters, the emotions, and especially the incredible performance of Yahya Abdul-Mateen II and Sir Ben Kingsley. They are a real team - the bromance and chemistry they share carry the show. Yahya was born for this role; he really shines and makes the character feel alive and relatable.

The first two episodes were a bit slow and didn't have any big deals, but from episode three onward, it was phenomenal. The series grows into itself, rewarding patience with clever writing, heart, and humor.

In the bigger picture, Wonder Man is exactly what the MCU needed right now. It makes me feel like Marvel is back this year, and honestly, never dead.

If you skipped it because of the trailer, you are missing out on a big thing, bro. Trust me - it's a must-watch, even if you've never watched MCU before.

title: Wonder Man
author: seraph66

There are hundreds of normal boring drama shows out already, but when I pick something with the Marvel logo, it's because I want fun escapism, not long drawn out conversations about nothing. Save your time and re-watch Thor Ragnarok again.

title: Wonder Man
author: giveyoubacklife

I have absolutely no idea how or more importantly why would they disregard that story and create this instead. It just doesn't make any sense.

title: Wonder Man
author: MohammadS-6357
review_title: A Character First, a Superhero Second"
review:
In an era where the MCU increasingly prioritizes spectacle over substance, Wonder Man stands out by doing something surprisingly rare: it takes time to build a character before asking us to cheer for a hero. Instead of throwing another powered individual into a city-saving montage, the series focuses on identity, loneliness, guilt, and self-control-making Simon Williams one of the more relatable protagonists Marvel has introduced in recent years.

Simon's journey is not about discovering power, but about learning how to live with it. His need to control outcomes, his struggle with perfection, and his isolation feel human rather than heroic. Unlike many recent MCU characters-where powers appear suddenly and purpose follows immediately-Wonder Man allows its lead to remain flawed, uncertain, and emotionally grounded.

Trevor Slattery's return is another unexpected strength. Once used primarily as comic relief, he is given emotional weight here. His guilt, quiet sacrifice, and guidance transform him into a mentor figure, reinforcing the show's central theme: identity is something earned, not performed. His dynamic with Simon mirrors the series' larger message about authenticity over image.

This approach places Wonder Man closer in spirit to Iron Man (2008) and Loki (Season 1) than to many recent MCU entries. Like Tony Stark, Simon's arc begins with ego and gradually shifts toward responsibility. And like Loki, the series prioritizes internal conflict over external battles. However, unlike projects such as Ms. Marvel, Captain Marvel, or She-Hulk, where character development often feels rushed or secondary, Wonder Man earns its emotional beats through patience and restraint.

That said, viewers expecting constant superhero action may find the series subdued. This is not a fight-driven show, and it doesn't try to be. Its strength lies in introspection, not escalation.

Ultimately, Wonder Man succeeds because it remembers what the MCU once did best: making audiences care about the person before the powers. If Marvel wants to combat superhero fatigue, this kind of writing isn't optional-it's essential.

title: Wonder Man
author: lanceanthony-87080
review: I have been a Marvel fan, since I was a boy. I am now in my 40's. Wonderman, was a major villain, then hero, in the comics. Marvel rushed the end of the Infinity saga. Wonderman, like several other characters, such have appeared much earlier. That aside, the writing and pace of comic book adaptations has massively improved since 2008. Wonderman feels like it would have been "okay" ten years ago. Like Cage and Iron Fist were released ten years ago. They both have greater death and breath, and as far as I'm aware, won't be continued. Marvel scaled back and cancelled projects to focus on greater quality productions. Wonderman is not that. This slot could have been filled with a Moon Knight season 2, which would have been much more appreciated by MCU and Marvel fans. I think attention needs to be paid to fans of the franchise. Where's the gambit we've been promised for years? Where's Blade? Where's Punisher? Moon Knight? This was just rubbish. To be getting scores of over 8, Kev must be paying people.

title: Wonder Man
author: ronniehrubin
review: I know nothing of superhero Wonder Man, but I like Ben Kingsley (and a fan of the MCU), so I figured, sure, why not. I watched the first episode and could not think of one reason to continue watching. The main character is completely unlikeable. Like others have said, this is a strikeout for Disney again.

title: Wonder Man
author: jjoyner-51053
review: I cannot express how disappointing this series has been so far. The casting, storyline, everything lacks appeal. I don't understand why it's so hard to bring quality, comic book based content to the screen when everything has been practically given to you, gift wrapped in the form of the comic books themselves. Unless a drastic, positive change happens in the near future, Marvel may have to accept the reality that they peaked with Avengers End Game.

title: Wonder Man
author: Supermanfan-13
review: Wonder Man is the new Marvel series on Disney+ and so far most of them have been hit or miss, I've really enjoyed some and been kind of disappointed by the others. Wonder Man definitely goes into the enjoyed category. I love that they released all 8 episodes at once because this works best as a binge watch. You're not going to want to wait a week between episodes and you don't have to. It's gotten nothing but great reviews as it currently has 90% on Rotten Tomatoes. Bottom line is Wonder Man is an original and fun show which is what you want from a superhero series.

title: Wonder Man
author: coldpizza_5o4
review: I went in thinking this show would be terrible because of the binge model; I was totally wrong this show was astonishing character study. Simon' character is relatable to people with big dreams and the question will you eventually succumb because of failures. The Duo of Yahya & Ben Kingsley doesn't look like it would work but it does amazingly. This is real writing and directing none of that MCU cheese in the dialogue. If this wasn't Marvel/Disney it could come off as a passion project the creators behind this show really put the time and effort to make this show great!

title: Wonder Man
author: Rob1331
review_title: Better than I thought it would be
review: Marvel's Wonder Man was even better than I expected. It's about a Hollywood actor named Simon Williams who gets a part as a superhero as he develops real super powers of his own. I have to say that it was a lot funnier than I though it would be too but what makes the show really good is the performances from the cast, specifically Yahya Abdul-Mateen II and Ben Kingsley. Everyone already knows what a great actor Kingsley is but Abdul-Mateen really shows what a good actor he is here. I'm looking forward to seeing more from him in his career going forward. If you're looking for a good show to watch where you can just turn your mind off and enjoy then give this a try.

title: Wonder Man
author: arrownik
review:
The "Wonder" is Why I'm Still Watching I sat down with my popcorn expecting the next big MCU spectacle, but after eight episodes of Wonder Man, I feel like I've been scammed. If you're in India and you've grown up on high-octane mass cinema or even the peak Infinity War era, this show is going to feel like watching paint dry in slow motion.

Why it Fails (Badly): Where is the Action? We were promised a superhero, but we got a struggling actor. Simon Williams (Yahya Abdul-Mateen II) spends more time worrying about his "process" and "self-tapes" than actually using his powers. In a country where we love our heroes to be larger-than-life, Simon is just... a guy who's bad at auditions.

The Trevor Slattery Problem: I know Ben Kingsley is a legend, but bringing back Trevor Slattery for this much screen time? It's just old men talking about the "theatre" and "artistic integrity." I didn't tune into Marvel to watch a meta-commentary on the 80s film industry.

The "Marvel Spotlight" Trap: They called this a "grounded" story. In reality, that's just code for "we didn't have the budget for CGI." The few times Simon actually uses his powers, it's over in seconds. It's a superhero show that is allergic to being a superhero show.

The Runtime: Each episode is barely 30 minutes, yet it feels like three hours. The pacing is sluggish, and the "satire" of Hollywood feels incredibly Western and disconnected from what makes a show engaging for us here.

title: Wonder Man
author: r-nelsch
review: Anyone ratings this over 1 star is paid or a bot. This series in unwatchable. The single dumbest Marvel concept ever created. Whomever gave this script a green light needs to be immediately fired and blacklisted from ever writing for TV again. The entire premise of the show is a waste of time to watch show to show. They made the main character so stupid its painful to watch.

title: Wonder Man
author: ohhhhcalvin
review:
So, of all of the god-awful content that KF has generated, this is the one he was concerned about? Sometimes the universe is just too ironic to stand. This is a great show with some great acting and great writing. I can hardly believe I'm saying this, but for all the great possibilities that the Marvel universe has failed to deliver on, to the rousing failure that this property has become this is the happiest mistake imaginable!

Here's to hoping he continues to trip over his own 2 feet. May Marvel and we, as the viewer be subject to monumental failures for the foreseeable future!

Watch this show you will love it. This is like THE STUDIO meets SUPERMAN THE MOVIE(1978). It's as rich a pedigree as it sounds.

title: Wonder Man
author: MysticSky123
review: Wonder Man this, and Wonder Man that, but nobody noticed that they didn't even show us how he got his powers. Pretty disappointing. Also, I was expecting more showcasing of his powers at least in the last episode, but we didn't even got that as well. Instead, we got a backstory of being a superhero of some random character.

title: Wonder Man
author: bluchargevoltage
review_title: So Good You Forget It's Marvel
review: This show is a fantastic and refreshing break from a lot of the less than satisfactory shows and movies marvel has been releasing lately. The much more grounded story with a focus away from the action is a unique view on the world of the MCU, and Simon and Trevor's view is the perfect way to tell it. Wonder Man manages to deliver a powerful story of growth while not only building up a great new character, but serving as the perfect end for the story of a long beloved one. Episode 4 was the best. However, the ending of Epsiode 8 left much to be desired.

title: Wonder Man
author: qwityurbichin
review: Marvel just knows what to do. They tell human stories, and they use superpowers to magnify the human condition. This is another example of a story that is just expertly told with emotion and comedy. There's little thing's I might change if it was a perfect world, but overall the story and performances are top notch. I also like the way my expectations were subverted. It reminded me of She-Hulk in a way that it's not the usual superhero story. This doesn't fit in a mold at all. It's a story of friendship, human relationships, and the way we help and hurt each other. It's life put in motion on the small screen, and i truly hope Marvel has more like this coming. Also, I loved seeing the Mandarin from Iron Man 3 and Shang Chi brought back. Iron Man 3 was the first Marvel project i remember breaking the mold, and I love that they keep showing a willingness to experiment and put story first.

title: Wonder Man
author: LeonardoOliva69
review_title: Bromance gives us one of the best series in the MCU, but with almost no connections...
review:
It seems that Marvel, when we least expected it, gave us a real gem.

What's happening with "Wonder Man" is something that hasn't been seen in previous years. Word of mouth has allowed a series without prior marketing, and perhaps with many people who weren't even aware of its premiere, to become one of the best in the MCU.

And what's even worse is that it doesn't follow the typical formula of the other series and has no connections to the others.

We knew Yahya Abdul-Mateen II from the wonderful and underrated "Watchmen" series and for being Black Manta in the "Aquaman" movies. This man truly has an incredible presence, without a doubt. He has a bearing that not everyone can maintain, and he's one of the pillars and cornerstones for this to work.

On the other hand, we have Trevor Slattery, played by the always reliable Ben Kingsley, whom we all hate because of "Iron Man 3." Both in the Shang-Chi movie and here, his character undergoes a complete transformation and acquires such complexity that we fully empathize with him.

But we can't forget that the showrunner of that series was also on "Shang-Chi" and "Spider-Man," so it's clear he's someone who does excellent work.

It's clearly an experimental series, both in its episode length and because they were all released simultaneously, but also because narratively we have a fifth episode that we didn't know we needed. With Doorman's backstory, we understand why Simon is the way he is and why he tries to hide everything.

The entire whirlwind of Hollywood in this universe, how people struggle daily to achieve their dreams, and how we witness the evolution episode after episode is truly remarkable.

The ending, honestly, I think, along with "Loki," are the best in the MCU series, and that's saying a lot (or rather, not much). Just as we haven't heard anything about Moonknight for 4 years, the same will surely happen with the escapades of Simon Williams and Trevor Slattery...we'll see if that's the case or not.

title: Wonder Man
author: john-lancia-1
review:
So Wonderman doesn't want to be wonderman because its going to get in the way of his acting career. Silly.

I realize that the creators of this show, who are so deeply immersed in the plastic and fake entertainment industry probably think that what they're doing is really important and really makes a difference in peoples lives. But the fact of the matter is that it doesn't. Its just entertainment.

No one, who wasn't mentally impaired, would choose being an actor over a superhero/supervillain. That the creators of the show think that this is a valid plot point says more about them than it does for anything close to human behaviour.

I guess this silliness passes for deep serious writing in Hollywood, but it seems ridiculous out here in real life.
